newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ PASSES BILL REMOVING SUPERANNUATION SURCHARGE.
newsitem.headline: NZ PASSES BILL REMOVING SUPERANNUATION SURCHARGE.

text.p: Parliament on Thursday rubber-stamped legislation removing the superannuation surcharge, the New Zealand Press Association reported.
The Taxation (Superannuitant Surcharge Abolition) Bill passed its final reading without opposition, meaning around 70,000 pensioners currently paying the tax will no longer have to from next April.
The bill had been introduced last month by Treasurer Winston Peters, whose New Zealand First party extracted a promise from National during last year's coalition talks to repeal the tax.
The surtax currently affects retired superannuitants with private income of more than NZ$297 a week for couples and $198 a week for single people.
Its abolition will cost the government around $550 million in lost tax revenue over the three years to 1999/2000.
Peters told Parliament the surcharge was discriminatory and penalised self-reliance, and its repeal was a "proud day for the coalition".
